page.lettertext:
fol.212r
Belgia [bis] 1594 24 June
Maye it please your good L: having nothing to negotiat till I heare
from your L: which I have not done as yet sins I came out of
England
I am humbly to beseech you, yf you thincke it soe meete, to lette me
know as soone as maye be to w
at
effect I shall addresse my further
dealing with the
States.
They have taken suche order for supplie
of the garrisons, as it is not to be doubted, but
e enemies forces beyng
presentlie dispersed they are very well provided, as yeat theyr mea-
ning is further as occasion shall requyre to see them furnished as
fully as they have bin at any time: I have alsoe earnestly
sollicited to know an answear about
e Shipping which
e Provinces will
send to
e enterprise of
Brittanie,
wherein I doe perceave by private
c
o
munication with some of their Deputies, that they have full com-
mission sent unto them, to take what order they thincke meete.
But for as much as my selfe am utterlie ignorant, both of
e number
of Shippes,
at her Ma
tie
will arme, and of the time
t
is assigned of
their putting to Sea; and of other besides very necessarie pointes to be
knowne to them heere, before they can resolve. I am forced to forbeare
from dealing further with them, till her Hig
es
further pleasure be
notified unto me. From the Campe before
Groeninghen
we are
thus advertised. That the 13 daye of this moneth the Bourghers
made offer to capitulat with
Co: Maurice
, requesting him to send
his Deputies unto them: which he promised to doe, soe that they
would send him hostages, till
e Deputies returned, where unto when
they had yealded
e Co. sent his Trompette to conduct
e hostages
unto him. But while the Trompet was within
e soldiers of
Verdugo
which laye intrenched in
e Suburbes, and were as is thought 700
in number, by
e practise of Jesuits, and with assistance of certain
mariners, and such others of
e towne as disliked to capitulat, had
a gate sette open to them, by which they entred unwares to
e
contrarie faction, put many to
e sword
at were in consultation,
advaunced their ensignes about
e walles of
e towne, and co
m
itted
besydes divers insolent actes. This was done
e 15 of this present,
but was unknowne to our armie, till a Bourgher that escaped and
lepte over the walles, came to tell it Co: Maurice, wherupon the
nexte daye after he sent them a Dr
u
me, to requyre his trompette
and to know their resolution. In the tyme of their parley,
fol.212v
it was accorded on both sides
at
e great Artillerie should not playe, which
was a singular furtherance to
e finishing of our workes, having pearced
by
at meanes into 4 severall places of their dyke, which now they la-
bour to fill up. The 17 daye at night
e trompett beyng returned,
Co: Maurice was certefied
t
e Bourghers had prevailed against
e
Soldiers of Verdugo, and had driven them againe into their trenches
in the Suburbes, which is called there
e
Schuytendiep
. And presently
upon it they renued their further sute, by a l
re
to
e Count requesting
him againe to capitulate with them, wherunto he condescended, but re-
fusing to be bownde as he had done before, not to use his great Artillery
which he perceaved by some pris
o
ners did more terrifie the Bourghers,
with their firie bullets, then anie other force or practise of
e Armie.
They required in lyke m
a
ner
at although they should conferre, and
agree upon conditions, they might yet be permitted to take 14 dayes
respite, to see what succo
r
woul d come to them, which they seemed to
demand, because Co: Maurice once before had seemed to make them
such an offer. Howbeyt by his l
re
of
e 19 he replyed unto them,
at
thinges were now in an other estate, and sith that before they reje-
cted his offer, he would not graunt soe much agayne, but in
e
worde of a Prince he would assure them
at was no succo
r
towardes,
using speeches of persuasion to drawe them to compownde without fur-
ther delaye. How this l
re
is accepted we doe not understand:
but everie man supposeth, and their manner of proceeding doth in-
sinuat no lesse, but
at they purpose to surrender.
Having had
e sight of an Abstract of
e
Emperors
proposition in
e Diet of
Ratisbone
, I thought
at if yo
r
L. had not seene it before,
I should not doe amisse to imparte it unto you, for which I send it
heere inclosed.
And soe I take my humble leave.
From
e Haghe. June 24
1594.
